posts.name: Lyle Oxley
posts.cooked:
Our team added the handles (shown below) to the bumpers to make it easier to pickup.   We don’t see anything in the rules that would prevent this, but wanted to get additional feedback to ensure this isn’t a problem.

Would this be allowed? image 715×516 64.7 KB

image 715×516 64.7 KB

image 715×516 64.7 KB

posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: yeah that’s fine, but I would think you may want to add the handles to the chassis rather than the bumpers.

We use eye bolts into the corners of the chassis with clip on weight lifting handles. All 4 corners allow you to grab it from the front and back or side to side, which can be handy when positioning the robot on the field, on the cart or in the shop

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.custom_user_title: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
What does it look like when the bumpers are installed on the robot?  Do these handles stay inside the bumper zone (within 7.5" of the floor, R402)?  An inspector might feel that this part of the bumper was “articulated, relative to the FRAME PERIMETER” (R403).  Worst case is that they would ask you to remove them.

I would be concerned about people using these to lift the robot.

Depending on the inspector it may breeze through or get a review by the LRI .  I don’t see anything that directly violates a bumper rule since it is part of an attachment system.

That being said.  I would advise against it.  From experience the interface between a wood screw and the bumper wood often degrades over an event and the screws can loosen or fall out.  At some point the rigid connection that is there now likely will not be there in the future and this could cause the robot to drop unexpectedly when trying to transport it in this manner.

I think you should find a more rigid connection on the robot frame to add the handles.

posts.name: The Imagery Queen
posts.cooked:
ParaKnight:

Would this be allowed?

This is allowed but not recommended. Remember that bumper structure is mostly wood while your chassis is metal and more structurally stable. Also, bumper wood can break during matches and be hidden under fabric. If you pick up the robot via the bumpers with weakened wood, it will not end well.

Edit: People are going to respond and provide advice. Let us know if you need ideas where to put handles!

posts.name: Lyle Oxley
posts.cooked: Thanks for everyone’s feedback.  We will take a second look on how to better secure the handles.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
The best thing would be to try to get an usable answer from Q&A. They tend to be pretty picky on restricting bumpers to what is specifically listed in the bumper rules.

+1 on trying to have a safe way to carry your robot.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
We have been putting handles on our robot since last year as our drive team is currently all-girl and it was too strenuous for them to lift the robot without them.

You can see a picture of the handles there (in orange):

FRC 2495: Hive Mind 2024 Robot - Maestro - FIRST / Robot Showcase - Chief Delphi

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Not just for girls.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Lifting handles are great for everyone.  It’s not necessarily a question of strength, but often more a question of location and ability to grip, and a question of being able to lift things correctly, using the right muscle groups.  Teams that have to reach underneath their bumpers to lift their robot are setting themselves up to lift things improperly.  Gripping that low, especially when you have to reach 4-5 inches in because of the bumpers, often leads to students lifting with their back instead of their legs.  Moving the grip point a little higher, and making it more accessible, makes it much easier to practice proper lifting form, preventing injuries and making it easier for anyone, regardless of gender or physical strength, to lift the robot.  Ask those same people to lift it in less ideal conditions, and many would struggle - I see it all the time at the inspection scale!

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
FrankJ:

Not just for girls.

Jon_Stratis:

Lifting handles are great for everyone.

Yes of course, I love the handles too. I should have simply written that we realized recently that having handles on the robot needed to be an essential requirement rather than an afterthought.

We also like very much that we can take the cart on the field this year, which we do.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
We have been incorporating holes in our structure for lifting straps for some time. You can see them in the corners. I am one of the few that were around when we didn’t. We don’t even find unusual to have programmers move the robot. PXL_20240310_172435202 1920×2560 401 KB

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Thor5090:

We use eye bolts into the corners of the chassis…

We used to use that method as well and I really liked it,  This year we have corner-biased swerve modules which means we have no frame corners to attach our eye-bolts to.  We thought about putting them at the ends of the frame (where they die into the swerve modules), but as we built a smallish robot that would put the two handles essentially side-by-side which would be very tippy especially if the CG falls outside of them.

This year we’re just lifting by the underside of the bumpers, which IMO is far from ideal, but as we are sub-100lbs it is doable.  Definitely would like to think up something better for next year.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We always use swerve guards bolted to the frame perimeter. Technically it is the frame perimeter. Just cut a hole in them. Picture of them a couple of posts above. You can see the normal ones in the back almost out of frame.

My team puts the handles on the chassis rather than the bumper so that we dont have to worry when we replace bumpers or worrying about breaking the bumpers from stress or something. But also I’m super happy seeing teams worry about handles. I remember my coach saying that carrying the robot on and off the field is probably one of the most dangerous things in robotics because you can’t exactly make safety protocols for that kind of stuff.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
We used eyebolts integrated into our swerve modules in 2020, we chose to put them away from the corner just to avoid the entanglement potential. Here is what the back of the robot looked like (straps installed and dangling down):

IMG_0979 1920×1440 240 KB

IMG_0979 1920×1440 240 KB

IMG_0979 1920×1440 240 KB

Worked great!

The straps were from amazon. I wanted to get some that said “REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT” to remind the students to remove them. But the orange ones worked well enough.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: I’m assuming those are home built swerves?   Our ( COTS ) ones don’t look nearly so sturdy, so I have definite concerns about lifting the robot through ours.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
Yes, those were our custom swerve.

However…

The eyebolts that were used for lifting were installed in place of 1/4"-20 bolts that were used as part of the assembly of those modules.

Similarly, with COTS modules, you could replace one of the 10-32 bolts that attaches the module to the frame rails with a 10-32 eyebolt. The trick is to get an eyebolt with a long threaded portion and then install a nut (nylock works best) onto the bolt upside down and thread it all the way toward the eye. Then install the eyebolt through the frame and install a second nut on the other end. You can then tighten the two nuts to get achieve the clamp and still have the eye.

If you look closely in the picture I posted above, you can see the other 3 black oxide hex head cap screws in the other 3 corners of the module and then you can see the nut that is installed on the shank of the eyebolt that is used to clamp the 4th corner once the eyebolt is threaded into the standoff below it.

Good luck finding any load bearing 10-32 eye bolts. We ended up just drilling and tapping one of the extra 10-32 bolt hloes to 1/4-20 then used a jam nut under the plate. We then purchased some exercise equipment handles off of Amazon because the students complained that the regular fabric strap squished their fingers. Some of our alumni that stop by from time to time complain to the mentors that we make it too easy for the kids now
